quiz.title: Chemistry Grade 11: Unit 3 Quiz 9
quiz.subtitle: 3.9: Valence Bond Theory: Hybridization $sp, sp^2, sp^3$
quiz.subject: Chemistry

questions.question: What is the primary purpose of orbital hybridization in Valence Bond Theory?
options: To explain molecular geometries that standard atomic orbitals cannot account for
To increase the total number of electrons in an atom
To allow the nucleus to expand and hold more neutrons
To convert covalent bonds into ionic bonds
questions.explanation: Hybridization mixes native atomic orbitals (like $s$ and $p$) to create new hybrid orbitals that match the observed VSEPR shapes and bond angles.

questions.question: Which hybridization state corresponds to a tetrahedral electron-group geometry?
questions.explanation: Combining one $s$ and three $p$ orbitals creates four equivalent $sp^3$ hybrid orbitals directed toward the corners of a tetrahedron.

questions.question: An atom with $sp^2$ hybridization will have how many unhybridized $p$ orbitals remaining?
questions.explanation: Since only two of the three available $p$ orbitals are used for $sp^2$ hybrids, one $p$ orbital remains unchanged and is typically used for pi ($\pi$) bonding.

questions.question: What is the hybridization of the Carbon atom in Carbon Dioxide ($\text{CO}_2$)?
questions.explanation: Carbon in $\text{CO}_2$ has two electron domains (linear), which requires $sp$ hybridization.

questions.question: In Ethene ($\text{C}_2\text{H}_4$), each Carbon atom is $sp^2$ hybridized. What type of bond is formed by the unhybridized $p$ orbitals?
questions.explanation: Side-to-side overlap of unhybridized $p$ orbitals creates a $\pi$ bond, which is the second component of a double bond.

questions.question: Which bond angle is associated with $sp^2$ hybrid orbitals?
questions.explanation: The three $sp^2$ hybrid orbitals arrange themselves in a trigonal planar geometry with $120^{\circ}$ angles.

questions.question: What is the hybridization of Oxygen in a water ($\text{H}_2\text{O}$) molecule?
questions.explanation: Oxygen has four electron domains (2 bonds + 2 lone pairs), which requires four $sp^3$ hybrid orbitals.

questions.question: How many sigma ($\sigma$) bonds and pi ($\pi$) bonds are in a triple bond?
questions.explanation: The first bond between atoms is always a $\sigma$ bond (head-on overlap). Any additional bonds are $\pi$ bonds (side-on overlap).

questions.question: Which of the following molecules contains $sp$ hybridized Carbon atoms?
questions.explanation: In Ethyne (acetylene), the carbons are triply bonded and linear, characteristic of $sp$ hybridization.

questions.question: A sigma ($\sigma$) bond is characterized by:
options: Head-to-head overlap of orbitals with electron density along the bond axis
Side-to-side overlap of orbitals with electron density above and below the axis
The transfer of electrons from a metal to a non-metal
The attraction between two nuclei without orbital overlap
questions.explanation: Sigma bonds are the strongest covalent bonds and are formed by the direct overlap of hybrid or atomic orbitals along the internuclear axis.

scoreMessages.90: Excellent! You have a deep understanding of orbital mixing.
scoreMessages.70: Great job. You're making strong connections between VSEPR and Valence Bond Theory.
scoreMessages.50: Good effort. Remember: 2 domains = sp, 3 = sp², 4 = sp³.
scoreMessages.0: Review the relationship between electron-group geometry and hybridization states.
